Graphical abstract Catalytic activity is highly affected by the zeolite matrix. The high dispersion of V and Mo oxide species on the exchange sites of zeolite and the high accessibility of active sites to the reactants play a key role in ethylene ammoxidation. This work reports on the investigation of the influence of the parent zeolite topology (MFI, MOR and USY) on the ammoxidation of ethylene to acetonitrile over vanadium and molybdenum oxide supported zeolite catalysts. The physico-chemical properties were investigated by several characterization techniques such as XRD, N2-adsorption, 27Al MAS NMR, TEM, XPS, DR UV–vis, Raman and DRIFT spectroscopies and H2-TPR. From the catalytic results, V and Mo oxide species in USY and MOR zeolites led to less active catalysts when compared to MFI structure. These results suggest that the catalytic performances depend strongly on the zeolite structure and thus, the size of the formed metal oxide particles. The catalytic activity and selectivity are controlled by the porous structure and the chemical state of V and Mo species. The extent of dispersion and reducibility of supported M-O x (MV or Mo) species are governed by the chemical identity of the support as detected by TPR analysis and optical absorption spectroscopy. The good catalytic performance of MFI-type zeolite might be related to the high dispersion of metal oxide species and to the internal pore space which permits an effective accessibility of the reactants. Keywords Molybdenum Vanadium Zeolite Solid-state ion exchange Ammoxidation 1 Introduction Ammoxidation of ethylene into acetonitrile has been the subject of great interest in recent years because acetonitrile is basically used as a solvent and as an educt in several organic and inorganic syntheses [1,2]. In addition the nitrile group can be easily converted by means of hydrogenation, hydration or hydrolysis reactions to amines, amides, imines and other functional groups which are very useful compounds in polymer and pharmaceutical industry [3]. Acetonitrile is typically obtained as a by-product during propylene ammoxidation to acrylonitrile [4]. But recent developments have indicated the possibility of selective one-stage synthesis of acetonitrile from ethane and ethylene by ammoxidation [5–7]. There is considerable interest in converting light alkanes directly to higher value organic chemicals because of the low cost and abundance of the alkanes. However, alkanes are chemically stable, which poses a tremendous challenge to achieve a high selectivity in their conversions. As an alternative, many research groups [7,8] have reported that ethylene can be efficiently converted to acetonitrile by ammoxidation since ethylene is a reactive hydrocarbon and a major intermediate product for the ethane ammoxidation reaction. Recent literature has focused on the design and development of active and selective catalysts that can allow the effective transformation of olefins into nitriles. Current commercial catalysts for nitrile production are based on metal oxides or supported metal oxides such as vanadium oxide, combined with other metal oxides like MoO3 or WO3. However, metal oxide-like systems were not found to be highly active in ammoxidation of ethylene to acetonitrile. In the past few years, zeolites have been used as efficient support for catalysts in the ammoxidation reaction. Recently, Li and Armor [6,7], Mies et al. [9] and Mhamdi et al. [10–13] found that Co/zeolite and Cr/zeolite based catalysts afford much better performance with a very high reaction rate and selectivity to acetonitrile than previously reported metal oxide catalysts. It is well known that at low loading, transition metal ions (TMIs) in zeolites preferably occupy exchange sites and preferentially coordinate with the framework oxygen atoms. As a consequence TMIs are present in the form of isolated species after exchange, as Lewis-acid centers, with a high site density not usually achievable by bulk or supported metal oxides. However, metal oxide particles located at the zeolite external surface and/or in the void zeolite space can be formed during the ion exchange process and/or during subsequent calcination which exhibit different redox properties compared to the cationic species. In addition, it has been demonstrated that isolated and oligonuclear metal species in the zeolite channels are the active sites in ammoxidation of light hydrocarbons [14]. Molybdenum containing zeolite catalysts have been found to be effective in the conversion of methane into aromatic compounds such as benzene [15,16] and in ammoxidation of propane to acrylonitrile [17], and there is interest for optimizing these catalysts in terms of selectivity and activity. In recent years, more and more attention has been paid to the incorporation of various transition metals particularly the vanadium [18–20] to molybdenum-based parent catalysts in order to achieve more satisfactory catalytic performance. Besides the metal, the nature of support employed in terms of surface area, metal-support interaction and acid-basic sites influence the catalytic performance. It has been shown that the type of zeolite structure is an important factor affecting the activity of catalysts. The comparison between different kinds of zeolites as supports can be useful for understanding the nature of interaction existing between the support and the active site. In view of the potential use of zeolites as a catalyst support, in the present study, a series of V-Mo-zeolite catalysts with different zeolite structures (MFI, MOR and USY) were prepared and characterized by several characterization techniques. The main objective was to analyze the effect of the zeolite topologies on the physicochemical properties of V and Mo exchanged solids and their catalytic behavior in the ammoxidation of ethylene into acetonitrile. To the best of our knowledge, there are only a few reports in the literature on the usage of bimetallic zeolite based catalysts for ammoxidation reactions in general and ethylene in particular. Against this background, the present study is aimed at exploring the potential of various bimetallic exchanged (V and Mo) zeolites based catalysts for the ammoxidation of ethylene to acetonitrile. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Parent zeolites: H-ZSM-5 (Si/Al=15), NH4-MOR (Si/Al=10) and H-USY (Si/Al=15) are commercial samples supplied by Zeolyst, Zeocat and Rhodia, respectively, that were used as support materials. Vanadium and molybdenum were supported onto zeolite by solid-state ion exchange method in two steps. At first, 1g of zeolite and ammonium metavanadate NH4VO3 (98%, PROLABO) with a vanadium content of 2wt% were finely ground and mixed in a mortar for 15min at ambient conditions. The resulting mixture was then heated in a helium flow (30mL/min) up to 500°C (heating rate: 2K/min) and left at 500°C overnight (12h). Then the obtained solid was finely ground and mixed with the molybdenum acetylacetonate precursor (98%, MERCK) in the molar ratio ((V+Mo)/Al=1 in the case of ZSM-5 zeolite) and heated again for 12h at 500°C in a flow of helium. Finally the catalysts were calcined in oxygen for 1h at 500°C. The prepared V-Mo-Z catalysts are denoted as VxMoy-Z, where x means vanadium content (2wt%), y is the (V+Mo)/Al molar ratio and Z is the parent zeolite (MOR, USY, ZSM-5). V2-ZSM-5, Mo1-ZSM-5 and V2O5/ZSM-5 solids serve as references in catalytic runs. V2-ZSM-5 and Mo1-ZSM-5 samples were prepared by mixing in a mortar, i.e., 1g of H-ZSM-5 and NH4VO3 (2wt%) or molybdenum acetylacetonate (molar ratio Mo/Al=1), followed by helium treatment at 500°C for 12h (30cm3/min, heating rate 2K/min). In addition, V2O5/ZSM-5 solid was also prepared by mixing in a mortar, i.e., 1g of H-ZSM-5 and V2O5 (2wt%; 99%, MERCK). 2.2 Catalysts characterization The surface area of the catalyst samples and the adsorption/desorption isotherms were determined with a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 analyzer by nitrogen adsorption at −196°C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on an X-ray Diffractometer from PANalytical using Cu-Kα radiation. A step scan mode was applied at 0.2°/min and structural data for reference compounds were taken from the ASTM X-ray powder data files. The elemental analysis (Mo, V, Si, Al) of the catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP, Optima 3000XL, PerkinElmer). UV–vis spectra of Mo and V species were monitored on UV–vis spectrophotometer PerkinElmer Lambda 45 equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment with an integrating sphere coated with BaSO4 (DR UV–vis). BaSO4 was chosen as diluent to minimize absorbance as well as used as baseline standard. FTIR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer (Spectrum BX) spectrometer in the wavenumber range 4000–400cm−1 using the KBr technique. Spectra were recorded in air using a 4cm−1 resolution. Raman spectra were obtained with a confocal Thermo Scientific DXR Raman device using a laser source at 532nm. 27Al MAS NMR spectra were recorded at 78.20609MHz on a Bruker WB spectrometer using AlClO3·6H2O as reference. An overall 4096 free induction decays were accumulated. The excitation pulse and recycle time were 6s and 0.06s, respectively. DRIFTS experiments were carried out with a Bruker IFS 55 spectrometer equipped with a Thermo Spectra Tech reacting cell at a spectral resolution of 4cm−1 and accumulating 200 scans. Samples were treated in situ at 500°C under helium (ramp: 5K/min, flow: 30cm3/min). H2-TPR (temperature programmed reduction) analysis was performed with a Micromeritics Autochem 2910 Analyser using a quartz U-tube reactor and an on-line thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for gas analyses. The catalyst (70mg) was dried at 500°C for 1h in air and reduced from 50 to 1000°C (10K/min) under 5% H2/Ar flow. NH3-TPD (temperature programmed desorption) analysis was performed with a Micromeritics Autochem 2910 analyzer. As the automatic NH3-TPD program included a pretreatment in air, the sample (40mg) was first exposed to an air flow (10cm3/min) at 500°C for 1h, then saturated with flowing ammonia at 100°C and flushed with helium at the same temperature. Finally, the temperature was ramped to 700°C at a rate of 10K/min. Quantitative analysis was performed by means of a TCD. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies of the samples were performed using a JEOL JEM-2100 FX microscope at 200kV, with a CCD ORIUS SC1000 (Model 832) camera and XEDS (OXFORD INCA) microanalysis system. The samples were prepared by grinding and ultrasonic dispersal in methanolic solution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out with an Omicron spectrometer equipped with an EA-125 hemispherical electron multichannel analyzer and a source of X-ray provided by Mg filament (Kα) having radiation energy of 1253.6eV at 150W and a pass energy of 50eV. The samples (0.02g) were slightly pressed into small pellets of 15mm diameter and then mounted on the sample holder. Every sample was introduced into the chamber where they were degassed for 6–8h, in order to achieve a dynamic vacuum below 10−8 Pa prior to analysis. Spectra were analyzed with CasaXPS software and RSF database by fitting after Shirley background correction. Ammoxidation of ethylene was carried out in a fixed bed down flow micro reactor at ambient pressure. The amount of catalyst used was 0.05g for all runs. In general, the inlet reactant composition was 10% O2 (Air Liquide 99.995%), 10% C2H4 (Air Liquide 99.995%) and 10% NH3 (Air Liquide 99.96%). The total flow rate was 100cm3/min by balancing with helium (Air Liquide 99.998%). Product gases were analyzed on-line by two gas chromatographic units, one operated with a flame ionization detector (FID) for analysis of organic compounds, while the other was equipped with a TCD for the analysis of permanent gases. The conversion and product selectivity are defined as follow: C o n v e r s i o n , X = ∑ i y i n i y E n E + ∑ i y i n i S e l e c t i v i t y of reaction product (carbon basis) , S = i y i n i ∑ i y i n i Yield of product P i (carbon basis), Y i = X × S i, where y i and y E are the mole fractions of product and ethylene respectively; n i and n E are the number of carbon atoms in each molecule of reaction product and ethylene, respectively. 3 Results 3.1 Chemical analysis The elemental analysis results of parent zeolites and V-Mo-Z solids including V, Mo and Al contents and Si/Al molar ratios are compiled in Table 1 . The values obtained for Si and Al fit well with the data provided by the zeolite manufacturers. On the other hand, the V and Mo contents analyzed in the catalysts are in good agreement with those of theoretical (nominal) values. Thus, it can be stated that neither molybdenum nor vanadium is lost during the solid-state reaction for example by sublimation. All the metals loaded are either on the external surface of the zeolite crystals or diffused inside its channels. 3.2 XRD patterns The XRD patterns of the V-Mo-Z catalysts along with the parent zeolites are shown in Fig. 1 . The similarity of the XRD patterns between the parent zeolite and the modified zeolite indicates that the framework of each support is still retained during the solid state reaction. Compared with the zeolite pattern, the intensities of peaks of V-Mo-Z catalysts decreased. As known, the low-angle XRD intensities in the pattern of zeolite are sensitive to the presence of any species inside the channels [21]. The decrease of peaks intensities of angle 2θ <10° in the pattern of V-Mo-Z also implies the entrance of molybdenum and vanadium into the channels. Furthermore, the intensities of the corresponding peaks of angle 2θ >10° decrease slightly implying that the crystallinity of the catalysts is slightly decreased after the thermal treatment. However, crystalline phases corresponding to either molybdenum or vanadium oxides were not detected in the V-Mo-Z samples. This fact suggests that the metal oxide species (i.e., oxides, cations,…) seem to be X-ray amorphous, i.e., they are present as small crystallites (in general, particles smaller than 4nm cannot be detected by XRD) or dispersed on the external surface of zeolite crystals, or even penetrated into the channels of zeolite as much smaller species during the thermal treatment procedure. 3.3 Textural properties obtained by N2-physisorption Table 2 summarizes the textural properties obtained from the N2-adsorption/desorption isotherms of the zeolite samples and catalysts. The parent zeolites show type I isotherm characteristic for microporous materials, although the V-Mo-Z catalysts show type IV isotherm characteristic for mesoporous materials with a region of a strong N2-adsorption at higher partial pressures. The literature [22] shows that metal ions were merely deposited on the external surface of zeolites as oxide aggregates which might contribute to the calculations of textural data and such solids exhibit some degree of mesoporosity. It is seen that the exchange process was accompanied by a decrease of surface area and porous volume of the support due to the presence of oxide aggregates or alumino-molybdate species that partially block the pores inside or at the entrance of channels of the zeolite. This effect is more pronounced over V2Mo-MOR catalyst. For V2Mo-MOR sample, surface area is approximately 89% lower than that corresponding to the parent zeolite (35 vs. 313m2/g). This strong diminution of the surface area is related to the loss of crystallinity of zeolite (as was previously demonstrated by means of XRD analysis), and to the occlusion of pore windows by small polymolybdate or alumino-molybdate species. 3.4 TEM/EDX studies TEM images of V-Mo-Z catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 a–c. Some of the oxide particles are indicated by arrows and the size of the M-O x clusters was estimated by measuring the diameter of the M-O x clusters visible in the microscope. For V2Mo-MOR and V2Mo-USY catalysts (Fig. 2a and b), the distribution of V and Mo over the catalyst surface was heterogeneous, as was examined by EDX analysis (spectrum not shown) and spherical oxide particles with size smaller than 40Å are detected at the surface. EDX analysis showed that some segments of the sample contain vanadium whereas other parts of the sample did not contain any vanadium at all. In the case of V2Mo-MOR, probably, the exchange sites situated in hidden positions (side pockets) being hardly accessible to Mo and V ions and hence reduce the diffusion of these ions to the exchange sites. Concerning V2Mo-USY catalyst, the number of accessible sites is limited by the small channels of hexagonal prisms. So V and Mo are possibly deposited mainly on the external zeolite surface as small oxide particles. Fig. 2c shows the TEM image of V2Mo-ZSM-5. No oxide clusters were observed. This result suggests that the particle size is very small and the particles may possibly exist inside the pores in a highly dispersed form, since the detection limit of the microscope is estimated at 5Å. The absence of Mo or V signals in the EDX analyses (spectrum not shown) of these samples indicates that the metal oxide species are well dispersed through the zeolite structure and mainly located in the cationic sites of the zeolite ZSM-5. 3.5 FTIR spectra Fig. 3 shows the FTIR spectra of the solid-state reaction products in the wavenumber regions of 1100–400cm−1. The deposition of the vanadium and/or molybdenum in the zeolites showed an absorption band in the region 900–910cm−1. This band is attributed to the stretching vibration of SiOM+ groups [23–25]. This is generally regarded as a proof of the incorporation of the heteroatom into the zeolite framework. According to bibliographic data, the band located at 900–910cm−1 is assigned to the MoO vibration in the tetrahedral molybdate species bound to the surface like (O3Mo O)2− species [26]. It should be noted that the allocation of this band was also advanced for Ti and V introduced in molecular sieves [27,28]. 3.6 DRIFT spectroscopy The results of the DRIFTS studies of V-Mo-Z solids are depicted in Fig. 4 . Spectra of parent zeolites are also included as References The spectrum of zeolite ZSM-5 revealed the presence of three bands, a band situated at 3610cm−1 attributed to strong Brönsted acid sites (SiOHAl) [29,30], a second band at 3664cm−1 attributed to the vibrations of AlOH groups [31,32] and a third band observed at 3740cm−1 assigned to the terminal silanol groups (SiOH) [33]. The spectrum of the MOR showed four bands. The first one situated at 3730cm−1 can be assigned to SiOH silanol group [34], a second band at 3670cm−1 ascribed to the vibrations of AlOH groups [35] and another band detected at 3600cm−1 could be due to the hydroxyl acid SiOHAl groups [34,35]. The fourth broad band centered at 3250cm−1 is attributed to residual ammonium ions [36]. The spectrum of USY zeolite exhibits a band at 3729cm−1 corresponding to the vibrations of silanol groups [34], and two other bands of low intensity located at 3612cm−1 and 3546cm−1, which can be attributed to the vibrations of Brönsted acid sites situated in the supercages (High Frequency band) and sodalite cages (Low Frequency band) of USY zeolite [29], respectively. After introduction of vanadium and molybdenum, DRIFTS spectra of different supports significantly change. In the case of ZSM-5, the intensities of the bands assigned to strong Brönsted acid sites (SiOHAl) and that attributed to bridging silanols (i.e., SiOH) were significantly reduced. This result suggests that the exchange with V and Mo concerned Brönsted acid sites and the silanol groups, which are not exchangeable with cations, are modified by grafting or are masked by the oxide species. The band assigned to AlOH species must be acidic because it disappeared upon exchanging with V and Mo ions. In the case of mordenite, the broad band intensity decreases, indicating that NH4 + cations were exchanged by V and Mo ions. However, the intensity of the band attributed to Brönsted acid sites SiOHAl was increased. This may be due to the formation of hydroxyl groups linked to the molybdenum like MoOH as it was already proposed in the case of ZSM-5 zeolite exchanged with Co ions. In the case of USY, the intensities of hydroxyl bands at 3612cm−1 and 3546cm−1 were significantly reduced evidencing that the exchange concerned Brönsted acid sites in supercages and sodalite cages. Obviously, a part of this decrease may be due to physical covering of hydroxyls groups by oxide species since the exchange sites situated in sodalite cages (small pores of the zeolite USY) are hardly accessible to Mo ions. We also noted that the intensity of the band situated at 3729cm−1 decreases, evidencing that a great part of V and Mo ions is grafted on silanol groups. 3.7 27Al MAS-NMR results 27Al MAS-NMR has been used as an efficient probe to determine the coordination, the local structure and the geometry of specific aluminum species in zeolites. 27Al MAS-NMR spectra of both the support ZSM-5 and zeolite catalysts are portrayed in Fig. 5 . The spectra show a peak centered at 0ppm that corresponds to the octahedral non-framework Al species [37] and a strong signal centered at 55ppm corresponding to the different tetrahedral framework Al species [38] that can be observed on all these samples. Doping V and Mo ions in the exchange sites of zeolite slightly decreases the intensity of tetrahedral Al peak but the resonance signals at 0ppm were sharply increased, suggesting that M-O x species interacted with the framework and modifies the coordination environments of the framework Al species. Moreover, some of them might become NMR invisible due to their lower symmetry. This result is in agreement with IR spectroscopy observations, which can be explained by a protolysis reaction between vanadium and molybdenum species and Brönsted acid sites. Moreover, for Mo1-ZSM-5 and V2Mo1-ZSM-5 samples, a new peak at about −14ppm appears which can be attributed to the octahedral aluminum in Al2(MoO4)3 phase [39,40]. It seems that the interaction between Mo species and the ZSM-5 support is so strong due to the high molybdenum loading, that aluminum is extracted by Mo species from the zeolitic framework, and finally leads to the formation of Al2(MoO4)3 phase. Nevertheless, this new aluminum molybdate phase was not detected by XRD on the Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst. Based on these results, we suggest that Al2(MoO4)3 may be formed in amorphous phase or small Al2(MoO4)3 crystallites are present in either at nanocrystalline state having less than 4nm in diameter (i.e., below the detection limit of XRD). 3.8 NH3-TPD studies NH3-TPD was performed to determine the acidic properties of the catalysts. NH3-TPD profiles of various catalysts as well as pure supports are illustrated in Fig. 6 a–f. For the parent zeolites ZSM-5 and MOR, two peaks of ammonia desorption can be observed in the NH3-TPD profile. The first one, located in the low temperature (peak ‘l’), could be assigned to the desorption of ammonia chemisorbed and/or physisorbed on the acid sites of Lewis or Brönsted centers with low force [41] or by silanol groups [42], whereas the second one located in the high temperature region (peak ‘h’) is attributed to the adsorbed NH3 molecules over the strong Brönsted acid sites. Upon V and Mo exchange in zeolite, more than two peaks can be observed. As shown in Fig. 6b and f, the area of the two peaks decreased compared with the parent zeolites when loaded with molybdenum and vanadium. It can be seen that the decrease of the peak ‘h’ was more pronounced, and the peak position shifted to lower temperatures in comparison with that of ZSM-5 and MOR zeolites. The peak with medium strength (peak ‘m’) appeared after modification of parent zeolites by M-O x species. We consider that M-O x species react with strong exchangeable Brönsted acid sites situated on the external surface or within the channels of zeolite during modification and generate a new kinds of medium strength acid sites, and therefore peak ‘m’ is probably associated with the desorption of ammonia adsorbed on these newly generated acid sites. The NH3-TPD profile of USY zeolite shows three peaks of ammonia desorption located at 200, 381 and 555°C that can be attributed to three types of acid sites. A detailed study of the acidity of this zeolite was reported by Boréave et al. [43]. They found three types of sites in terms of acid strength for USY zeolite: weak, intermediate, and strong. The weak sites were mostly of Lewis type resulting from the degradation of the crystalline structure of the zeolite. The sites of intermediate strength were found to be mostly of Brönsted type, and were associated with the bridged −OH groups of the structure that are surrounded by less than three second-nearest neighboring aluminum atoms. The strong sites were corresponding to both the structural and extra-framework −OH groups, as well as aluminum atoms that are either extra-framework or associated with framework defects. After solid-state ion exchange, the areas of peaks corresponding to the intermediate and strong acid sites disappear. Based on these results it is suggested that an exchange of V and Mo in USY inhibits the strong and intermediate acidity and generates a new acid sites with different properties. It is also accepted that the extra-framework Al species neutralized a part of strong acid sites. 3.9 DR UV–vis spectroscopy Fig. 7 depicts the ultraviolet diffuse reflectance spectra between 200 and 800nm regions for the V-Mo-Z samples. The absence of the dd band expected in the range 500–800nm for V4+ or Mo5+ ions in the spectrum of all catalysts can be explained by the absence of paramagnetic ions. In contrast, the presence of two bands at 240 and 300nm attributed to oxygen-tetrahedral V5+charge-transfer (CT) transitions (π) t 2 →(d) e and (π) t 1 →(d) e. This result indicates that vanadium is present as diamagnetic V5+ species (d°) in tetrahedral coordination [44]. The presence of a band near 400–500nm suggests that this sample contain a low amount of square pyramidal or distorted octahedral V5+ species. The samples exhibited two other bands at about 215 and 280nm, which can be assigned to Mo6+ ions surrounded by oxygen anions in tetrahedral symmetry and to the dimer or polymerized molybdate species [45,46], respectively. An absorption band was observed at around 325nm, which was due to poly-molybdena clusters of MoO3 crystallites [47]. However, in XRD analysis of the V-Mo-Z catalysts we could not observe any peak of MoO3 because of the detection limit of XRD (i.e., X-ray amorphous nature of such species). The information obtained through UV–vis spectroscopy on the band gap energy is extremely useful in evaluating the dispersion and local coordination environments of supported M-O x species over different supports [48,49]. The edge energy is obtained from the intercept of a straight line fitted through the rise of the function [F(R∞) hv]1/2 plotted vs. hv (fig. 8 ), where F(R∞) is the Kubelka-Munk function, hv is the energy of the incident photon. The energy at the absorption edge has been recently used to characterize the size of MoO x [50] and VO x [51] domains in catalytic active solids. The values thus obtained carry information about the average domain size of the oxide species since, as for the case of a particle in a box, the band gap energy decreases as the domain size increases [50]. The results obtained for the band gap energy are reported in Fig. 8. On MOR and USY supported catalysts, edge energies reach very low values (2.4–2.5eV) than ZSM-5 support with the same vanadium and molybdenum content, indicating the formation of highly agglomerated M-O x species. This result indicates that the support influences the apparent dispersion and absorption edge energy of M-O x species. For V2Mo1-ZSM-5 catalyst the energy gap shifts to higher values, indicating a decrease in the number of next nearest neighbors of the M-O x species [52]. These band energy values (Eg=2.9eV) indicate the formation of isolated surface M-O x species. As expected, ZSM-5 zeolite appears to disperse M-O x units more effectively than other supports. This behavior can be attributed especially to the different pore systems of supports which influence the accessibility to the Brönsted acid sites inside the zeolite crystals. 3.10 Raman spectroscopy Fig. 9 a–c shows the Raman spectra of Mo1-ZSM-5 and V-Mo-Z catalysts. The Raman spectra of Mo1-ZSM-5 sample exhibit a Raman band at 995cm−1, characteristic of the MoO stretching mode of surface mono-oxo molybdenum oxide species [53]. The Raman bands observed at 819 and 667cm−1 should be attributed to the asymmetric stretching mode of Mo O Mo in MoO3 crystallites and to polymeric molybdate species [53], respectively. Also, a weak band appeared at around 285cm−1 corresponding to the bending mode of MoO bonds in MoO3 oxide [53]. The spectra of V-Mo-Z catalysts exhibit Raman bands similar to those observed in Mo1-ZSM-5 sample. It must be noted that the characteristic bands of vanadium species have not been detected in all catalysts, probably, due to a high dispersion of V species. Moreover, the absence of a band at around 775cm−1, that has been related to the presence of V O Mo vibrations for poly-molybdo-vanadate species, permit us to suggest that a Mo O V phase is not formed in our catalysts. These results are in good agreement with the UV–vis results. However, we cannot completely discard a change in the nature of Mo or V species although the MoVO species have not been detected by Raman spectroscopy. 3.11 XPS studies The specific binding energies of the Mo 3d3/2 and V 2p3/2 XPS peaks and elemental composition of the near-surface region are given in Table 3 . The binding energies in the XPS spectra were corrected by referencing the C 1s 284.6eV. It is not possible to fit the broadened spectra with two or three sets of doublets, representing individual Mo5+ or Mo4+ [54]. Then the XPS spectra are fitted by 100% Gaussian distribution. The main constraint in fitting the curves is that the BE difference ΔEB of Mo 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 must be 3.10±0.05eV, to ensure that the results have physical sense [55]. Fig. 10 a–d and Fig. 11 a–e present the XPS results for V-Mo-Z samples. The XPS spectra (Fig. 10a–d) of Mo consist of two peaks representing the Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2. The binding energies of Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 correspond well with characteristic Mo6+ according to literature [56]. Moreover, the broadening of XPS peaks has been attributed to various factors such as (1) the presence of more than one type of Mo6+ with different chemical characteristics which cannot be discerned by XPS and (2) electron transfer between Mo and support (metal-support interaction) [56]. Based on the results obtained in the presence of reference V2O5/ZSM-5 solid (Fig. 11a), only the V 2p3/2 line can be used for data analysis, since the V 2p1/2 component is superimposed by the O 1s signal. Since the loading of vanadium was only 2wt%, the intensity of the V 2p peak was very weak. The V 2p3/2 BEs of V-Mo-Z catalysts are in the range of 516.8–514.1eV (Table 3), lower than that of V2O5 (517.4eV) reported in the literature [57]. In our case, the negative shift in BEs of V 2p3/2 relative to V2O5 is surprising. In no case was observed UV–vis absorptions around 600nm that might be assigned to dd transitions of V4+ detected. Moreover, the vanadium exchanged zeolite was subjected to calcination treatments that should also oxidize clustered V4+. On the other hand, the absence of XRD reflections for vanadium compounds in our samples indicates that these clusters are well dispersed and either very small or amorphous. It is well known that the UHV conditions cause a significant reduction of small V species on the surface of the catalyst. In addition, the surface composition of a solid can be altered by ion bombardment due to the preferential sputtering of atoms with the lowest mass. This effect has been shown for oxides like MoO3, Nb2O5, TiO2 and V2O5 for example, where the preferential sputtering of the oxygen atoms causes a surface reduction [58]. Thus, one can conclude that the UHV conditions and the interaction of the X-rays with the zeolite surface during the XPS measurements can cause reduction of V oxide species which are initially present in the highest oxidation state. However, the presence of a minor fraction of Mo5+ or V4+, which are rather stable even under oxidizing conditions, cannot be totally excluded. The (V+Mo)/Al atom ratios of bulk composition determined by chemical analysis are much larger than that of XPS results (Fig. 12 ) which confirm the migration of vanadium and molybdenum species into the zeolite matrix during solid-state reaction. The metallic ions anchored on the inner walls of the pores are undetectable by XPS technique, which is at about 40Å depths. On the other hand, the V: Al atom ratios of bulk composition are much larger than that of XPS results which indicates that the vanadium is mainly located in the exchange sites inside the pores. One could speculate that the small size of the V precursor, NH4VO3 would allow the introduction of VO x species in the internal surface of the zeolite. In the case of V2Mo-MOR sample the Mo/Al atomic ratios obtained by XPS exceed the bulk values, which indicates that the external surface region is enriched in molybdenum, whereas, in the case of other samples a considerable part of molybdenum ions are loaded on cationic positions. The anchoring of Mo species to zeolite support could be described by the following reaction: (1) Z–OH+MoO2(acac)2 →ZOMoO2(acac)+acacH. During the calcination of the catalyst precursors, the remaining ligands of the Mo complex are removed and MoO x species are formed. For the mordenite sample (mono-dimensional pore system), the reaction (1) would not be accomplished in the internal channels of the zeolite (12-ring channels (6.5×7.0Ǻ) and elliptical 8-ring channels (2.6×5.7Ǻ)) due to the large size of the acetylacetonate molecule (50Å). Thus, the MoO x species precursor would essentially be dispersed on the zeolite extra-framework surface or external surface. These results are in agreement with the optical absorption experiments which indicated the presence of agglomerated M-O x species in the case of V2Mo-MOR catalyst. 3.12 H2-TPR investigations Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) with H2 is a useful technique to probe the reducibility of catalytic materials. The reduction profiles of the catalytic samples are presented in Fig. 13 a–e. The reference V2-ZSM-5 sample (Fig. 13a) shows multiple reduction peaks, corresponding to the reduction of vanadia in different steps, i.e. from the oxidation state +5 to +3 in various surface vanadia species [59], whereas the reference Mo1-ZSM-5 sample (Fig. 13b) exhibits a peak at 595°C, attributed to Mo6+ reduction to Mo4+ in dispersed MoO x , and another peak at 830°C, corresponding to Mo4+ reduction to Mo° [60]. The reduction profile for V2Mo1-ZSM-5 displays three peaks corresponding to the reduction of Mo6+ into Mo4+, V5+ into V3+ and Mo4+ into Mo°. However, the reduction profiles for V2Mo-MOR shows only two peaks; the first peak is attributed to the simultaneous reduction of Mo6+ and V5+ to Mo4+ and V3+, respectively, while the second peak reflects the reduction of Mo4+ to Mo°. The reduction profiles for V2Mo-USY and V2Mo-MOR are very similar except for a slightly lowered temperature for the first reduction peak in V2Mo-USY (598 vs. 635°C). Table 4 lists the assignments of each reduction peak and the ratio H2/Me. This Table also reveals the expected (stoichiometric) consumption of H2 in each case. Measured H2 consumption ratios are very similar to those expected for the first reduction peak in Mo1-ZSM-5, V2Mo-USY and V2Mo-MOR samples. Thus, the TPR results would show that the aggregation of the molybdenum oxide species yields to a significant increase of the degree of catalyst reduction. We previously demonstrated that most of the molybdenum and vanadium species are located in the channels of the ZSM-5 zeolite as well-dispersed M-O x species while in the case of MOR and USY zeolites an isolated molybdenum trioxide or polymolybdenum oxide species appear on the external surface of the catalysts. The presence of small molybdenum aggregates in the V2Mo-MOR and V2Mo-USY catalysts was supported by TEM and DR UV–vis spectroscopic results. Surface enrichment of molybdenum species (XPS results) may be one of the causes for this observation, which will be dealt in the latter paragraphs. It has been reported for MoO3/SiO2 catalysts [60] that dispersed surface molybdenum species are less reducible than polymeric ones. The TPR profiles in Fig. 13 show that the V2Mo1-ZSM-5 sample is reduced at a higher temperature than that of Mo1-ZSM-5 suggesting that the surface species in the case of V-Mo-Z samples are more difficult to reduce than in Mo-Z sample. On the other hand measured H2 consumptions for reduction of MoO x and VO x species are smaller than expected for the reduction of Mo6+ and V5+ to Mo4+ and V3+, respectively, for V2Mo1-ZSM-5 samples. This finding indicates a change in the nature of MoO x or VO x species by interaction between vanadium and molybdenum species such as V-Mo oxo-structure containing V O Mo linkages which are less readily reducible than the MoO x or VO x species. According to TPR results, these hardly reducible species would be joined to the zeolite support and therefore well dispersed. 3.13 Catalytic activity Ammoxidation reaction of ethylene was carried out in the temperature range of 425–500°C. The catalytic results of the VMoZ catalysts are given in Table 5 . For all catalysts, a moderate increase of ethylene conversion (X-C2H4) and acetonitrile selectivity (S-ACN) could be seen across the temperature range. It is clear that the temperature has a highly pronounced promotional effect on the ammoxidation of ethylene into acetonitrile. ACN is the major product, while CO2 is the major by-product. In the case of the most active catalyst (V2Mo1-ZSM-5), the conversion of ethylene and the selectivity toward acetonitrile were observed to increase continuously from 2 to 14% and from 35 to 95% with rise in temperature from 425°C to 500°C, respectively. The enhancement in the catalytic properties might be attributed to the increase in the intrinsic activity of the existing active sites and also due to the creation of more active sites with rise in reaction temperature. 4 Discussion The effect of zeolite topology in ethylene conversion was clearly manifested. Our results, of the ammoxidation of ethylene indicate the following order of catalytic activity: V2Mo1-ZSM-5>V2Mo-MOR>V2Mo-USY V2Mo1-ZSM-5 catalyst showed much higher activity and selectivity toward acetonitrile compared to V2Mo-USY and V2Mo-MOR. These results suggest that the most active sites are located in MFI structure, while those in USY and mordenite exhibit lower activity. Similar results were also obtained by Ayari et al. [61] couple of years ago. The differences between the catalysts derived from ZSM-5 zeolite and other samples can be attributed especially to their different pore structures, which in turn can certainly influence the local environment of V and Mo species and the accessibility to the active sites inside the zeolite crystals. The ZSM-5 zeolite comprises three-dimensional interconnecting 10 ring pore of dimensions 5.5×5.1Ǻ and 5.3×5.6Ǻ [62], whereas USY has a three-dimensional interconnecting pore system with supercages of 11.8Ǻ connected by circular 12-ring 7.4Ǻ windows [62]. Mordenite has a bi-dimensional pore system, with parallel circular 12-ring channels (6.5×7.0Ǻ) and elliptical 8-ring channels (2.6×5.7Ǻ) [63]. The diffusion between the channels is not possible (except for very small molecules). Therefore, practically it functions as a mono-dimensional pore system since the 8-ring channels can be hardly accessible by usual molecules. In our study, the DRIFTS, NH3-TPD and 27Al-MAS-NMR results confirm the promotion of Mo and V ions in all catalysts, preferentially interacting with Brönsted OH groups localized inside the pore structure or at the external surface of the zeolite crystals. Crystalline V2O5 and MoO3 species were not detected on any of the supports. XPS and UV–vis spectroscopy data revealed that the structure of dispersed M-O x species depends on the nature of the support. M-O x dispersion is lower on MOR and USY than on ZSM-5 for the same vanadium and molybdenum content. TEM and XPS studies further confirm the conclusions derived from UV–vis spectra. Edge energies for V2Mo-MOR and V2Mo-USY were lower (2.4–2.5eV) than that for ZSM-5 support with the same vanadium and molybdenum content, suggesting larger M-O x domains (V2O5 and MoO3 clusters) on MOR and USY than on the ZSM-5 support. The high absorption energy on ZSM-5 (2.9eV) suggests the predominant presence of isolated M-O x species on this support. These results are also confirmed by the TPR experiments (quantification of the H2 uptake) which indicated that M-O x species joined to ZSM-5 support are well dispersed. The data in Table 5 demonstrate that ZSM-5-supported catalyst shows the highest activity and selectivity toward acetonitrile while the other catalysts give poor activity/selectivity. These changes in activity can be intimately correlated to the changes in the edge energy values and reducibility observed in the DR UV–vis and TPR experiments, respectively. The low activity of V2Mo-USY and V2Mo-MOR catalysts is caused by the poor dispersion of the M-O x species. In the case of V2Mo-USY catalyst, a considerable part of Mo and V oxide species are located in the supercages and in the “hidden” sodalite cavities. Active sites in the supercages are readily accessible for reagents through the 12-membered ring unlike the active sites in the sodalite cages, which are inaccessible to molecules that cannot diffuse through the six-membered oxygen ring. The fact that only a small fraction of its active sites can take part in the reaction would also explain the very poor activity of V2Mo-USY catalyst. As discussed above, the low activity of V2Mo-MOR reflects the low dispersion of M-O x species on this support. XPS data suggest that the external surface region of V2Mo-MOR catalyst is enriched with molybdenum. This result is in agreement with the DR UV–vis, TEM and TPR experiments that indicated the presence of easily reducible M-O x clusters (H2/(V+Mo) values). The presence of such small MoO3 clusters on the surface of this catalyst thereby creating a diffusion block for ethylene molecules, and inhibits the catalytic activity. Moreover, in mordenite supported catalyst there is not enough space for formation of the reactive intermediate which has been identified as ethylamine species (C2H5NH2). Furthermore, one-dimensional 12-ring channel system does not permit effective mixing of the reactants, which are however necessary for this reaction. Exchanging V and Mo ions with MFI-Type zeolite led to the highly active catalysts. On the basis of XPS, TEM and DR UV–vis data, we can suggest that M-O x species are well dispersed inside the channels of zeolite ZSM-5. The high dispersion of metals on exchange sites of MFI type zeolite rules out the possibility of pore blockage. The good catalytic behavior of V2Mo1-ZSM-5 may be associated with the presence of a significant number of small M-O x species (isolated mono or dimeric M-O x species…) stabilized by the interaction with the zeolite framework and located preferably in the straight or zigzag channels, which are readily accessible for guest molecules. This led to the conclusion that larger M-O x species are less active than small structure for ethylene ammoxidation. This was previously suggested by other authors [64] using zeolite ZSM-5 ion-exchanged with TMIs for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with hydrocarbons and direct N2O decomposition. It has been demonstrated that smaller extra-framework metal oxide species, including isolated and oligonuclear species in the zeolite channels, are the active site. 5 Conclusion The effect of zeolite topology (MFI, USY and MOR) in ethylene ammoxidation over V-Mo doped zeolites was clearly manifested. The prepared materials exhibited generally good activity and selectivity in the studied reaction. The following order of total catalytic activity: V2Mo1-ZSM-5>V2Mo-MOR>V2Mo-USY can be accounted. DR UV–vis, Raman, DRIFTS and XPS results showed that V and Mo species are, essentially, mono and/or polymetallate species located in the zeolite exchange sites or on the exterior surface as small oxide particles (TEM results). It was clearly demonstrated that the chemical state of V and Mo species, i.e., as isolated ions on ion exchange positions or as small oxide particles, affects the catalytic performance. XPS and UV–vis spectroscopy data show that the structure of dispersed M-O x species depends on the type of the support applied. M-O x dispersion is lower on MOR and USY than on ZSM-5 for the same vanadium and molybdenum content. Vanadium and molybdenum clusters resulted in a partial blocking of the pores and enhanced the selectivity toward CO2, however, small M-O x species (isolated mono or dimeric species…) are very active for ethylene ammoxidation. For V2Mo-USY and V2Mo-MOR catalysts, the small pores (6-membered oxygen ring and 8-ring channels, respectively) are hardly accessible to molecules which can explain the poor dispersion of the M-O x species. Results revealed strong evidence that the improved catalytic performance of V2Mo1-ZSM-5 catalyst is related to the high dispersion of V and Mo species on the exchange sites of zeolite and to the high accessibility of active sites to the reactants in such structure. coredata.dc:description: This work reports on the investigation of the influence of the parent zeolite topology (MFI, MOR and USY) on the ammoxidation of ethylene to acetonitrile over vanadium and molybdenum oxide supported zeolite catalysts. The physico-chemical properties were investigated by several characterization techniques such as XRD, N2-adsorption, 27Al MAS NMR, TEM, XPS, DR UV–vis, Raman and DRIFT spectroscopies and H2-TPR. From the catalytic results, V and Mo oxide species in USY and MOR zeolites led to less active catalysts when compared to MFI structure. These results suggest that the catalytic performances depend strongly on the zeolite structure and thus, the size of the formed metal oxide particles. The catalytic activity and selectivity are controlled by the porous structure and the chemical state of V and Mo species. The extent of dispersion and reducibility of supported M-O x (MV or Mo) species are governed by the chemical identity of the support as detected by TPR analysis and optical absorption spectroscopy. The good catalytic performance of MFI-type zeolite might be related to the high dispersion of metal oxide species and to the internal pore space which permits an effective accessibility of the reactants.
coredata.dc:title: Ammoxidation of ethylene to acetonitrile over vanadium and molybdenum supported zeolite catalysts prepared by solid-state ion exchange
